name: Soccer Manager 2015
description: If you love football as much as we do, you live and breathe it. Start managing your favourite club in a matter of minutes. Play in 48 leagues from 36 countries around the world and choose from over 800 clubs. Lead living legends to victory in this fast-paced, action-packed single-player game.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP or Later Processor: 1 GHz or higher Memory: 1 GB RAM Network: Broadband Internet connection

reviews.review_text: I was not epxecting much out of this game. But I was surprised in a good way. This game offered what I didn't think it would. But for now here is the basic pros and cons of this game:  *Positives* -free to play -licenses for all teams (unlike PES) -simple and clean UI -Very well written dialogue for the in-game commentaries -Player biography and faces add authenticity to the game  *Negatives* -there is no 2D map to watch your players play like in Football Manager -no soundtrack leaves you sort of audiably bored -a ton of microtransactions (expected from a free to play) -more customizations are necessary -no steam overlay -no achievements,mods,trading cards,etc. (will probably be added later)  Overall, the game is superb for being a free to play. But like all free to plays there are always the microtransactions which will hinder the game's experience.Updates in the future may fix the aforementioned negatives but the game offers so much and all you have to offer is nothing. If you dont pay the microtransactions its not the end of the world because you can still end up in your goal but it might take longer.Having all the licenses and player biographies/faces is quite impressive for a free to play whereas big corporations like Konami still struggle to get licenses.  So get this game and try it out. For me I will give this game a pretty solid 7.5/10. The game is great for a free to play but there are some hindering qualities that will hopefully update soon. But for now try it for yourselves!
For my full review check out it out on my video game blog   Game On!   [chrisspeerswrites.wordpress.com]     Soccer Manager vs Football Manger

**UPDATE - 24/07/2015** I want to confirm that the development team have handled my missing Save Game issue expertly and professionally and I am very grateful for their support. It was all dealt with inside a week any my lost funds/game have been restored. Good support = a really good and hard to find aspect of a game. Original review below.  In a nutshell - it's a free rip-off of Football Manager, drilled down to the essentials, and about a hundred times harder to do well which encourages you to pay for some in-game currency.  That said, the gameplay more than made up for the difficulty and considering a season of FM can take me anything up to a month to get through, to be able to get through a season in a couple of evenings in this 'FM-Lite' is a big plus. I happily laid down my £5 for in game currency to give me some breathing room to enjoy it even more.  Come on Braintree Town!
This game is actually a bit fun and simple to learn how to play. Worth a shot.

For a free game, this is great and can be quite addicting. However, I feel that there are some issues in the gameplay that I hope will be addressed. Your team's performance seems to be very much based on momentum. I've had huge winning streaks, and then as soon as it ends, the team just goes through a long stretch where they can't seem to win against anyone. Also, the player morale system is very difficult to work around. Once a player's morale drops to 30% or below, it seems extremely difficult to get it back up, no matter what you do. It feels like a vicious cycle where the player is not happy, then the low morale impacts the player's performance, then the poor performance by the player makes his morale drop even lower. In the end the only way out seems to be to sell the low morale players and try to buy new players without impacting the morale of your other players.
